com.avaya.csta.registration

Interface RegistrationServices


  • public interface RegistrationServices
    A service that allows applications to take control of Communication Manager phones/extensions and their media streams through a registration process. This service is an extension to the ECMA-269 CSTA specification. Registering a terminal gives the application access to the signaling and possibly the media of a DCP (digital) or IP telephone or extension that is administered for Softphone access on Communication Manager. (See Supported Telephone Configurations for more information.) Unregistering a device gives up control of the device. If a call is underway, redirecting the media stream causes the current media stream to be directed to the requested location; otherwise, it causes any future media stream to be directed to the requested location. Register a terminal before acting upon it with any of the API services and then unregister it when the application is through with it.

    NOTE: Registration and Unregistration are synchronous calls and can take a relatively long time. Since these are synchronous calls, the requests will block while waiting for a response. If it is desirable that the application thread be able to continue processing while waiting for the response, consider using AsynchronousServices to process the RegisterTerminalRequest and UnregisterTerminalRequest.

    In the registration request, you can set the media parameters and even request control of the media stream. This is done by setting the local media information in the registration request.

    Prerequisites Before using RegistrationServices, do the following:

    1. Get access to RegistrationServices through the ServiceProvider. For example: 
       RegistationServices registationSvcs =
   (RegistrationServices)servProv.getService(com.avaya.csta.registration.RegistrationServices.class.getName());
    2. Get a device ID for the phone or extension you wish to gain control of by using DeviceServices. For example: 
       // Put a GetDeviceID request together based on switch and extension.
 GetDeviceId devIDReq = new GetDeviceId();
 devIDReq.setSwitchName(switchName);
 devIDReq.setExtension(extension);

 // Use DeviceServices to request a device ID
 DeviceServices devSvcs =
  (DeviceServices)servProv.getService(com.avaya.csta.device.DeviceServices.class.getName())
 GetDeviceIdResponse devIDResp = devSvcs.getDeviceID(devIDReq);
 DeviceID deviceID = devIDResp.getDevice();
    3. Add the desired listeners. Monitor for server unregistration by implementing RegistrationListener and adding your listener implementation using addRegistrationListener. Monitor for media events on the device by implementing MediaControlListener and adding your listener implementation using addMediaControlListener. MediaControlListener will receive media events regardless of whether the media is controlled by the connector server or your application. You may wish to ignore media events if the media is controlled by the connector server. Media Events are not available when the device is registered in NONE or TELECOMMUTER mode.

    Clean Up When you are finished using the terminal, do the following:

    1. Unregister the terminal using the RegistrationServices.unregisterTerminal method.
    2. Remove any listeners that were added for that device using removeRegistrationListener and removeMediaControlListener.
    3. Release the device ID, using DeviceServices.
    Version:
    $Revision: 1.4 $
    Author:
    AVAYA, Inc.

    • Method Detail

      • registerTerminal

        RegisterTerminalResponse registerTerminal(RegisterTerminalRequest request)
                                   throws CstaException
        Registers a specific terminal with Communication Manager in order to gain control control over the phone or extension. See the RegisterTerminalRequest request for more information. The types of DCP and IP phones and extensions that can be controlled are described in Supported Telephone Configurations.

        For the following examples, please note that the method setSharedControl is deprecated and has been supplanted by setDependencyMode and setMediaMode.

        If you wish only to have access to the signalling of an endpoint (which is equivalent to what was formerly called "shared control"), your code to set up the RegisterTerminalRequest request may look like this: 

           RegisterTerminalRequest regReq = new RegisterTerminalRequest();
   regReq.setDevice(id);
   LoginInfo login = new LoginInfo();
   login.setPassword(password);
   login.setMediaMode(MediaMode.NONE);
   login.setDependencyMode(DependencyMode.DEPENDENT);
   regRequest.setLoginInfo(login);
        If you wish to have access to both the signaling and the media of an endpoint, your code to set up the RegisterTerminalRequest request may look like this: 
           RegisterTerminalRequest regReq = new RegisterTerminalRequest();
   regReq.setDevice(id);
   LoginInfo login = new LoginInfo();
   login.setPassword(password);
   login.setMediaMode(MediaMode.CLIENT);
   login.setDependencyMode(DependencyMode.DEPENDENT);
   regRequest.setLoginInfo(login);
   // Set regRequest's localMediaInfo parameter, since we're
   // using MediaMode.CLIENT.
   regRequest.setLocalMediaInfo(. . . .);
        A request to register using DependencyMode.INDEPENDENT can succeed even in the absence of another endpoint registered to that extension in DependencyMode.MAIN. Independent mode can be useful when, to achieve high availability, two instances of an application register on an extension that doesn't have an associated end-user telephone. One would register using DependencyMode.MAIN and the other using DependencyMode.INDEPENDENT. In this case, Communication Manager will allow either registrant to answer or make calls immediately after they register. Conversely, a request to register using DependencyMode.DEPENDENT cannot succeed unless another endpoint is already registered to that extension in DependencyMode.MAIN. If you wish to have primary access to the signaling and media of an extension (which is equivalent to what was formerly called "exclusive control"), set the dependency mode to DependencyMode.MAIN and the media mode to any mode but MediaMode.NONE. If you also want to change the preferred codecs, media encryption and/or packet size, then you will add: 
           MediaInfo localMediaInfo = new MediaInfo();
   
   String [] codecs = new String [2];
   codecs [0] = MediaConstants.G729;   // first choice
   codecs [1] = MediaConstants.G729A;  // second choice
   localMediaInfo.setCodecs (codecs);
   
   String [] encryption = new String [2];
   encryption [0] = MediaConstants.AES;          // first choice
   encryption [1] = MediaConstants.NOENCRYPTION; // second choice
   localMediaInfo.setEncryption (encryption);
   
   localmediaInfo.setPacketSize (new Integer (20));
   regReq.setLocalMediaInfo(localMediaInfo);
        If you want the media stream to terminate at the AE Services server, simply set mediaMode to MediaMode.SERVER. If you wan the media stream to terminate at at dialable extension (whether IP or hard phone), set the extension and set the MediaMode to MediaMode.TELECOMMUTER: 
         login.setTelecommuterExtension("1234567");
 login.setMediaMode(MediaMode.TELECOMMUTER);
        If you want the media stream to terminate at the application or some other application-specified IP address, then you will also insert code to set the RTP/RTCP address and set mediaMode to MediaMode.CLIENT like this: 
         //Set RTP address to an even address
 InetAddress inetAddress = InetAddress.getAllByName("hostname.example.com");
 IPAddress ipAddress = new IPAddress();
 ipAddress.setAddress(inetAddress.getAddress());
 ipAddress.setPort(9000);
 localMediaInfo.setRtpAddress(ipAddress);

 //Set RTCP address to next odd address
 ipAddress.setPort(9001);
 localMediaInfo.setRtcpAddress(ipAddress);
 
 // Set the required Media Mode 
 login.setMediaMode(MediaMode.CLIENT);
        After the RegisterTerminalRequest request is set up, send the request with code like this: 
           RegisterTerminalResponse regResp = registationSvcs.registerTerminal(regReq);
        If there is a problem with the request, an exception is thrown. The result of a registration is indicated by the response to this method.

        Registration is a synchronous process and can take a relatively long time. Since this is a synchronous call, this request will block while waiting for a response. If it is desirable that the application thread be able to continue processing while waiting for the response, consider using AsynchronousServices to process the RegisterTerminalRequest.

        If your application will control the media stream, then it will also need to monitor the media events. The MediaControlListener events that may be caused by a RegisterTerminalRequest request include:

        • MediaStartEvent
        • MediaStopEvent
        Parameters:
        request - the RegisterTerminalRequest request that contains the device ID, the device's password and other optional parameters to register the device.
        Returns:
        the RegisterTerminalResponse when RegistrationServices has accepted the request, and the request has been processed.
        Throws:
        InvalidDeviceIDException - if there is no station associated with the DeviceID or the format of DeviceID is not correct
        InvalidActiveDeviceStateException - if the station is in the process of registering or unregistering
        InvalidParameterValueException - if the password is NULL or the request is NULL or there is an invalid codec or invalid encryption specified
        InvalidDeviceStateException - if the device is already registered
        ParameterNotSupportedException - if unsupported parameters are used
        OperationException - if there is an operation error such as a socket IO exception error.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the request parameter is null
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs

      • unregisterTerminal

        UnregisterTerminalResponse unregisterTerminal(UnregisterTerminalRequest request)
                                       throws CstaException
        Unregisters the specified terminal from Communication Manager in order to give up control of the terminal. Be sure to unregister terminals when they are no longer needed. See the UnregisterTerminalRequest request for more information.

        Unregistration is a synchronous process and can take a relatively long time. Since this is a synchronous call, this request will block while waiting for a response. If it is desirable that the application thread be able to continue processing while waiting for the response, consider using AsynchronousServices to process the UnregisterTerminalRequest.

        Warning: If you fail to unregister the terminal, Communication Manager will keep the terminal registered to the connector server indefinitely.

        Parameters:
        request - the UnregisterTerminalRequest request that contains the DeviceID and other optional parameters required to unregister the device.
        Returns:
        the UnregisterTerminalResponse when RegistrationServices has processed the request.
        Throws:
        InvalidDeviceIDException - if there is no station associated with the device ID specified.
        InvalidDeviceStateException - if the device is in the wrong state.
        InvalidParameterValueException - if the request is NULL.
        OperationException - if there is an operation error such as a socket IO exception error
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs

      • redirectMedia

        RedirectMediaResponse redirectMedia(RedirectMediaRequest request)
                             throws CstaException
        Redirects the media stream of the previously registered device to a new address. This method can only be used if the given device was registered with MediaMode.CLIENT. It cannot be used to switch from client media mode to server media mode, or vice versa.

        Note: when using RedirectMediaRequest, the programmer is responsible for ensuring that the RTP and RTCP addresses specified in localMediaInfo are correct. If they are incorrect, then the media stream will be directed to the incorrect address and will be lost.

        Note: there is a limitation (bug) in CM that requires the RedirectMedia request to specify a different IP address for the RTP; otherwise the request will be ignored (a change in the port number only is ignored by CM). Thus, if you want to change only the port number of the media destination, it must be done in two steps:

        • Send a RedirectMedia request specifying an IP address of "0.0.0.0". This will cause CM to stop the media stream to the original client destination (but leave the call up).
        • Send a 2nd RedirectMedia request specifying the actual new destination for the media stream. Since this will involve specifying a new IP address (as well as a new port), CM will process this request correctly.

        An example of using this method is: 

         RedirectMediaRequest redirReq = new RedirectMediaRequest();
 MediaInfo localMediaInfo = new MediaInfo();

 localMediaInfo.setRtpAddress(newRTPAddress);
 localMediaInfo.setRtcpAddress(newRTCPAddress);
 
 redirReq.setDevice(id);
 redirReq.setLocalMediaInfo(localMediaInfo);
 redirReq.setUsePreviousValues(new Boolean(true));
        After the RedirectMediaRequest is set up, send the request as follows: 
           RedirectMediaResponse response = registrationSvcs.redirectMedia(redirReq);

        If there is a problem with the request, an exception is thrown. Both a MediaStopEvent and a MediaStartEvent will occur if a call is underway at the time a RedirectMediaRequest is received; otherwise, no media event will occur. If the extension is in multiple calls, the Communication Manager will send a MediaStopEvent for each of the calls. However, the Communication Manager will initially send a MediaStartEvent only for the active call. A MediaStartEvent for a held call will be sent once the held call becomes active.

        If you wish to use the same codec and encryption parameters for the new recipient of the media stream, call setUsePreviousValues with a true Boolean value. Otherwise, you may specify any valid, non-null values for the codec and encryption parameters.

        Note: there is a method available which allows you to specify a new RTP packetSize. However, the packetSize is actually controlled by Communication Manager, not by the client. Thus, any value specified in the setPacketSize method will be ignored.

        Parameters:
        request - the RedirectMediaRequest request that contains the DeviceId and localMediaInfo required to direct the media stream to a different device.
        Throws:
        InvalidDeviceIDException - if there is no station associated with the device ID specified.
        InvalidDeviceStateException - if the device is in the wrong state.
        InvalidParameterValueException - if the request is NULL.
        OperationException - if there is an operation error such as a socket IO exception error
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific excecption occurs

      • changeDeviceSecurityCode

        ChangeDeviceSecurityCodeResponse changeDeviceSecurityCode(ChangeDeviceSecurityCode request)
                                                   throws CstaException
        This API allows a DMCC client to change the security code of an extension on a Communication Manager. The switch connection must be administered on AES server for the Communication Manager (name/IP address) the client specifies in the DeviceID of the request. Switch name parameter in the DeviceID is required for this request to succeed.

        Note: When this API request is made, if a DMCC endpoint using the same deviceID is currently registered in MediaMode.CLIENT (or MediaMode.SERVER) media mode with RTP encryption enabled and Communication Manager is administered to use "challenge" authentication algorithm in the "network-region" form associated with the deviceID, then that endpoint must be un-registered and re-registered, after this API request is processed successfully.

        An endpoint registered in this manner, uses the security code for RTP encryption. And if the security code is changed via this API while it is registered it will not be able to decode the encrypted RTP packets for subsequent calls, unless it re-registers with the new security code.

        This is not an issue if the endpoint is not using RTP encryption. Also, this is not an issue if endpoint is using RTP encryption and the "authentication" algorithm administered for this deviceID is "pin-eke".

        A security code can only consist of characters ASCII a-z, A-Z, 0-9, "*" and "#". No other characters are allowed.

        An example of using this method is: 

         ChangeDeviceSecurityCode cdscReq = new ChangeDeviceSecurityCode();
            cdscReq.setDevice(deviceId);
            cdscReq.setOldSecurityCode(oldSecurityCode);
            cdscReq.setNewSecurityCode(newSecurityCode);
        After the ChangeDeviceSecurityCode request is set up, send the request as follows: 
           ChangeDeviceSecurityCodeResponse response = registrationSvcs.ChangeDeviceSecurityCode(cdscReq);

        Only one request is allowed at any time. If AES receives a second request for the same deviceID before the response to first request is sent, a CstaResourceBusyException will be thrown.

        If this request fails three consecutive times within 10 minutes, due to a bad securityCode, this API and ValidateDeviceSecurityCode API will be locked for this deviceID for the next 10 minutes.

        This request could fail for any of the following reasons:

        • Switch Connection is not administered on AES for the given Communication Manager address/name
        • Switch Connection to Communication Manager is not up
        • Communication Manager is older than CM5.1
        • Extension in the DeviceID is not administered on Communication Manager
        • Unknown internal error
        • Request to Communication Manager timed out
        • oldSecurityCode has invalid characters
        • newSecurityCode has invalid characters
        • Invalid oldSecurityCode
        • The new security code is an empty string
        • Communication Manager has a lock on station data, try again after few seconds
        • Communication Manager is busy processing a previous changeDeviceSecurityCode request
        Parameters:
        request - the ChangeDeviceSecurityCode request that contains the DeviceId, oldSecurityCode and newSecurityCode required to change the securityCode on the Communication Manager.
        Returns:
        ChangeDeviceSecurityCodeResponse when ChangeDeviceSecurityCode request has been processed.
        Throws:
        InvalidDeviceIDException - if device ID not specified.
        InvalidDeviceStateException - if device is locked state.
        InvalidParameterValueException - if switch name in the request is NULL or empty.
        ResourceBusyException - if AE Server is currently processing either this request or ValidateDeviceSecurityCode.
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs

      • validateDeviceSecurityCode

        ValidateDeviceSecurityCodeResponse validateDeviceSecurityCode(ValidateDeviceSecurityCode request)
                                                       throws CstaException
        This API allows a DMCC client to change the security code of an extension on a Communication Manager. The switch connection must be administered on AES server for the Communication Manager (name/IP address) the client specifies in the DeviceID of the request. Switch name parameter in the DeviceID is required for this request to succeed.

        Only one request is allowed at any time. If AES receives a second request for the same deviceID before the response to first request is sent, a CstaResourceBusyException will be thrown.

        If this request fails three consecutive times within 10 minutes, due to a bad securityCode, this API and ChangeDeviceSecurityCode API will be locked for this deviceID for the next 10 minutes.

        An example of using this method is: 

         ValidateDeviceSecurityCode vdscReq = new ValidateDeviceSecurityCode();
            vdscReq.setDevice(deviceId);
            vdscReq.setSecurityCode(oldSecurityCode);

        After the ValidateDeviceSecurityCode request is set up, send the request as follows: 

           ValidateDeviceSecurityCodeResponse response = registrationSvcs.ValidateDeviceSecurityCode(vdscReq);

        A security code can only consist of characters ASCII a-z, A-Z, 0-9, "*" and "#". No other characters are allowed.

        This request could fail for any of the following reasons:

        • Switch Connection is not administered on AES for the given Communication Manager address/name
        • Switch Connection to Communication Manager is not up
        • Communication Manager is older than CM5.1
        • Extension in the DeviceID is not administered on Communication Manager
        • Unknown internal error
        • Request to Communication Manager timed out
        • securityCode has invalid characters
        • Invalid securityCode
        • The security code is an empty string
        Parameters:
        request - the ValidateDeviceSecurityCodeResponse request that contains the DeviceId and securityCode required to validate the securityCode on the Communication Manager.
        Returns:
        ValidateDeviceSecurityCodeResponse when ValidateDeviceSecurityCode request has been processed.
        Throws:
        InvalidDeviceIDException - if device ID not specified.
        InvalidDeviceStateException - if device is locked state.
        InvalidParameterValueException - if switch name in the request is NULL or empty.
        ResourceBusyException - if AE Server is currently processing either this request or ChangeDeviceSecurityCode.
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs

      • getRegistrationState

        GetRegistrationStateResponse getRegistrationState(GetRegistrationState request)
                                           throws CstaException
        Returns the registration state and the gatekeeper IP address (if REGISTERED) for the requested device. See the GetRegistrationState request for more information.
        Parameters:
        request - the GetRegistrationState request that contains the DeviceID for which to get the registration state.
        Returns:
        the GetRegistrationStateResponse containing the RegistrationState indicating the registration state for the requested DeviceID
        Throws:
        InvalidDeviceIDException - if there is no station associated with the device ID specified.
        InvalidParameterValueException - if the request is NULL.
        OperationException - if there is an operation error such as a socket IO exception error
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs

      • getRegistrationInfo

        EndpointRegistrationInfoResponse getRegistrationInfo(EndpointRegistrationInfoRequest request)
                                              throws CstaException
        This on-demand request will retrieve the current registration information for a particular station. The requested registration information will be returned in the EndpointRegistrationInfoResponse and will include the information for up to four H.323 endpoints which may be registered against the specified device. This request may be used to supplement the information received by monitoring the EndpointRegistered and EndpointUnregistered events

        Parameters:
        request - specifies the desired device by DeviceID.
        Returns:
        the registration status data of the device in the EndpointRegistrationInfoResponse structure.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the EndpointRegistrationInfoRequest is null, the DeviceID within the EndpointRegistrationInfoRequest is null or the content within the DeviceID is null.
        OperationException - if the call information link is down or there were any kind of I/O problems during the requests across the call information link.
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs

      • selectiveStream

        SelectiveStreamResponse selectiveStream(SelectiveStreamRequest request)
                                 throws CstaException
        A 1PCC API for selectively receive media stream from one or more devices. Using this API user can request stream only from Agent, Everything except Agent or include or exclude few parties from the stream. An SelectiveStreamRequest API is available since 8.0.1.
        Parameters:
        request - the SelectiveStreamRequest request that contains the DeviceID for which the modified stream to be requested, and streamContent which specifies the content for the modified stream.
        Returns:
        the SelectiveStreamResponse
        Throws:
        CstaException
